War of 1861. Louisville
Claim for Widow's Pension. Act of July 14, 1862. 105072
Widow of
Claimant: Karen Chambers Private Co. G. 11th Regt. U.S.C. Troops
Residence: County and State of Ky.
Post Office address: Anderson, Ky.

Declaration and Information is not form.

Proof exhibited.

Section. The soldier was married Sept. 14, 1864, and is reported by the Adjutant General.

"Lied November 6, 1864, of disease in field Hospital Va."

Rank. Testimony of the 1st Sergeant of same Co. and Regt. that the soldier died late as officer of Dacron, contracted in the service, and that he was a man of sound, physical, being when he entered the camp a good soldier and of sobriety and well-badest. For other reasons testify to his sound condition at Milestown's Affidavit of Claimant that the officers of the Regt. being unknown were also available to procure a commissioned officer certificate etc.

Strategy. Proof of Exhibitism since 1857 and my opinion as man and wife by the community since that time and up to the time when he enlisted. No legal marriage the State law requiring time for persons of Color.

Name and Rank of Writer. (Print or type.)

Law Clerk. (Print or type.)

Law Clerk. (Print or type.)

Signature. (Print or type.) Area- address Claimant, Anderson, Ky.

Affidavit. (Print or type.) December 13, 1867, to a Pension of a Eighti per month.

Commencing. November 7, 1864.

P.H. Berkaw, Examining Clerk.

Appl. S. H.

(2-1876) 4,000.

Wm. B. H. Dearborn, Esq.

# Wilson's Application for Army Pension.

In case of a pension, the applicant must state in a form or form as shown in figure two, all the amount and value, in order for that, based on the fact that he has no claim for a pension, and that his name, and address, and the name of the person who claims the pension, is to the person he has given, and that he has no claim.

State of Kentucky County of Henderson in SS.

On this 21st day of August A.D. 1867 personally appeared before me (1) Clerk of the (2) County, (3) County, a Court of Record, acting and for the County and State aforesaid, Wm. B. H. Dearborn, a resident of the (3) County of Henderson in the State of Kentucky, and (4) State, who, being duly sworn according to law, doth on her oath make the following declaration in order to obtain the benefit of the provision made by the act of Congress, approved (4):

First, in the year 1866, That she is the widow of Aaron Chambers, deceased, and (5) Private, in Company "K" commanded by Captain John C. Green, in the 11th Regiment of (5) 1st, 12th, 13th, 14th, 15th, 16th, 17th, 18th, 19th, and 20th, in the 21st year of (6) 21st, 22nd, 23rd, 24th, 25th, 26th, 27th, and 28th, in the 29th year of (7) the 30th, and 31st, in the 4th year of (8) the 5th, and 6th, in the 7th year of (9) the 10th.

That he served in the aforesaid Aaron Chambers in the (1) County of Henderson in the State of Kentucky, and in the (2) of (3) (4) (5) (6) (7) (8) of the (9) of the (10) of the (11) of the (12) of the (13) of the (14) of the (15) of the (16) of the (17) of the (18) of the (19) of the (20) of the (21) of the (22) of the (23) of the (24) of the (25) of the (26) of the (27) of the (28) of the

That he served in the aforesaid Aaron Chambers, died on the day mentioned, and that she has remained a soldier over since that period, in still more fully appear by reference to the proof herewith accompanying or to the Executive filed, that she declares that she has not, in any manner, been engaged in or aided or abused, the selection of the United States.

She further, that she has been a Revolutionary Pensioner in the State of Kentucky, that her daughter, the widow of Thomas A. C. to the above named, died in the year 1867, at the time of the pension, from which she was a widow, and that she has not since been a Pensioner.

She further, that she has been a Pensioner since 1867.

ENCLOSURES

1. In testimony whereof, I have hereunto set my hand and seal of office, at Washington, D.C., this 12 day of August, 1890.

2. The foregoing declaration and affidavit, purporting to be his, are all to be executed before the same, and the same are all to be executed before the same, and the following are to be executed before the same, and the same are to be executed before the same, and the following are to be executed before the same, and the same are to be executed before the same, and the same are to be executed before the same, and the same are to be executed before the same, and the same are to be executed before the same, and the same are to be executed before the same, and the same are to be executed before the

Adjutant General's Office
Washington, D.C.
October 7th, 1867

Sir:

I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt from your Office of application for Pension No. 152714, and to return it herewith, with such information as is furnished by the files of this Office.

It appears from the Rolls on file in this Office, that Aaron Chamber was enrolled on the 19th day of Sept., 1861, at Owensboro, Ky., in Co. "G" 118th Regiment of U.S. Col. Infty Volunteers, to serve three years, or during the war, and mustered into service as a Private on the 19th day of Sept., 1861, at Owensboro, Ky., in Co. "G" 118th Regiment of U.S. Col. Infty Volunteers, to serve three years, or during the war. On the Muster Roll of Co. "G" of that Regiment, dated Hides Rendezvous, 2nd, 6th, 1862, he is reported "Recd. of disease in field Hospital Co. No. 6/61."

I am, Sir, very respectfully,
Your obedient servant,

E. W. Taggart

The Commissioner of Pensions
Washington, D.C.

Assistant Adjutant General
and Lieut. U.S. Army
In charge of Pension Act. of hospital

Memoranda
Name of applicant
Address

Surgeon General's Office,
Record and Pension Bureau,
Washington, D. C. Oct 10th, 1867.

Sir:

I have the honor to return herewith application for Pension, No. 152,744 with such information as is furnished by the records of this Office, Private
Maron Chambers, Co. "F" 118th
Regiment "U.S. C.T." is reported to this Office by Apr. each of
Surgeon's Hospital at New York as having died December 6", 1867, at
18" Army Corps Hosp.
of "Indiana"
"Circular Chapin Farm Co."

Very respectfully,
Your obedient servant,

BY ORDER OF THE SURGEON GENERAL:

J. J. Woodward
Brevet Major and Assistant Surgeon, U. S. A.

The Commissioner of Pensions,
Washington, D. C.

(Printed in U.S. Government, Washington, D.C.)
Head of Constitution—Time, Place, and Cause of Soldier's Death—Continued (illegible, etc.)

# JOINT AFFIDAVIT.
## ARMY PENSION—WIDOW CLAIMANT.

We, John Dixon, of lawful age, a resident of the (1) County of Richmond, in the State of Kentucky, at James Sutton, of lawful age, a resident of the (1) County of Richmond, in the State of Kentucky, upon our claim, jointly declare that he was personally well acquainted with Mrs. Kean Chambers, widow of (1) Aaron Chambers, now deceased, and was not sent to Private in Company E, commanded by Captain Moore, in the 1818 Regiment of (2) United States Colored Volunteers, commanded by Colonel Moore, in the war of 1776-1778.

We further declare that we were likewise personally well acquainted with the said (1) Aaron Chambers, deceased, and his said wife, the said Mrs. Kean Chambers, during the lifetime of the former, and know that they lived and exhibited together as husband and wife for the period at least of (2) Twenty years prior to his death, which length of time in the longest period of cohabitation, known to us. That said parties were reported as husband and wife, and that we never heard a question raised or a doubt concerned to the contrary as to their being such. Furthermore, we have often heard the said (1) Aaron Chambers call the said Mrs. Kean Chambers "wife," and always heard him speak of, and know that he ever treated and suspected her as such relation. We also state that she is esteemed and known as a respectable woman in the community of her residence.

We further declare that at the time of service, we resided in the army, established, County and State with the deceased soldier, and know that he, the said (1) Aaron Chambers, previous to his entering the said service of the United States, was a man of good sound physical health. Our knowledge of said soldier's physical condition prior to enlistment, as above stated, is finished upon several observations and intimate acquaintance with him and not heard upon information derived from others, nor upon general reason. That he died (1) While in the service aforesaid in the (1) United States, in the State of Virginia on or about the Sixth day of November A.D. 1864, from the effects of (2) Wounds, described in the service of the United States, and as we verily believe from general reports, and without the slightest doubt to the contrary, while in the line of his duty therein. That Mrs. Kean Chambers, his widow aforesaid, applying for Army Pension by reason of the above named military service, is now a widow, and has remained such ever since the death of her said husband, the said (1) Aaron Chambers, above mentioned. That we make this affidavit as a simple act of justice to the applicant, and for an other purpose, having an interest in so doing whatsoever. That we fully understand the import and meaning of all the facts embodied in this affidavit, and to which we freely testify.

B. E. Thornton
J. T. Weller
John Dixon
Justice of the Peace
Mark

Sworn to and subscribed before me on this 21st day of August in the year 1867, and I hereby certify that I know the affiants to be credible witnesses, and that they reside as stated in the foregoing joint affidavit. I also certify that said affidavit was read over to and understood by them, before they signed the same. I also certify that I am entirely disinterested in this matter.

B. E. Thornton
J. T. Weller
John Dixon
Justice of the Peace
Mark

State of New York County of Henderson, SS.

I, Laura P. Hockbridge, Clerk of the County Court within and for the County and State aforesaid, do hereby certify that R. S. Parr Esq., before whom the foregoing joint affidavit was made, and who has thereunto signed his name, was at the time of so doing a Notary in and for the County and State above named, duly commissioned, qualified and sworn; that all his official acts as such are entitled to full faith and credit, and that his said signature as it above appears is genuine. I further certify that, to the best of my knowledge and belief, the witnesses subscribing the foregoing affidavit are credible and of good standing in the community in which they reside. That I have no interest in this matter.

To certify all which I hereunto set my hand and the seal of my said Court at Office in the County and State aforesaid, A.D. 1868

R. S. Parr
J. P. Hockbridge
J. E. Swann
Clerk

State of Kentucky County of Madison SS:

I, Saml P. McMurtridy, Clerk of the County Court within and for the County and State aforesaid, do hereby certify that H. Y. Park Esq., before whom the foregoing affidavit, was made, and who has thereunto signed his name, was, at the time of so doing, a (2) Notary Public in and for the County and State above named, duly commissioned, qualified and sworn, that all of his official acts as such are entitled to full faith and credit, and that his said signature, as it appears on the reverse page hereof is genuine.

FOR GENERAL PURPOSES IN UNITED STATES CLAIM EVIDENCE.
A NEW RULE.

State of Kentucky County of Indiana SS.
On this 21st day of August A.D. 1867, before me H. S. Park, a Notary Public, I certify that the law of the State of Kentucky, is entitled to credit for the services rendered and paid by him, and that the pensioner is entitled to receive a pension of the 7th of July, 1866, being by me duly sworn according to law, on oath, that he is the true and lawful widow of Solomon Charles, decd. late a Private Company, Co. 111th U.S. Inf. Infantry, who died in field Hospital, State of Virginia, on the 21st day of November, 1866, from the affiant of Christian Anderson, for the time of duty.

She further declares she is unable to obtain a certificate from the Surgeon of this Regiment or Company, Virginia, for the reason that they were all withheld and do not reside in the Community of this residence, and in lieu of the above named certificate. She lives with said, the affidavit of two of his fellow soldiers, as to the cause and place of this death, not being the best evidence she is able to obtain.

She further swears, she cannot send record proof of her marriage with the above mentioned soldier, and for the reason that the law of the State, and not requiring a license to a record for the marriage of Charles of Color, but recognizing them as man and wife from the act of the Revolution, and she (Aaron) & her lived together as man and wife according to the law, in Kentucky, for persons of color, in proof of which she lives with and the affidavit of two or another witnesses.

Dennis C. Spinkers
Notary Public
ATTEST.
P. C. Thornton
S. T. Miller

Sworn to and subscribed before me, this 21st day of August, in the year 1867, and I hereby certify that the affiant is a respectable and credible person and made an oath, that I believe ——
and correct and worthy of full faith and credit, that I have no interest in this matter. I further certify that the foregoing affidavit was read, read, fully explained, to, and understood by the affiant before the signing and execution thereof, and also that the affiant is the identical party represented as making the affidavit.

H. S. Park
N. D. H. C.

GIVEN under my hand and seal of the said County Court at Office at Newbury in said District on the 11th day of August, 1849

J. P. Waldenington
of Newbury County Court.

Sir:

I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt from your Office of application for Pension No. 152714, and to return it herewith, with such information as is furnished by the files of this Office.

It appears from the Rolls on file in this Office, that Aaron Chamber was enrolled on the 19th day of Sept., 1861, at Owensboro, Ky., in Co. "G" 118th Regiment of U.S. Col. Infty Volunteers, to serve three years, or during the war, and mustered into service as a Private on the 19th day of Sept., 1861, at Owensboro, Ky., in Co. "G" 118th Regiment of U.S. Col. Infty Volunteers, to serve three years, or during the war. On the Muster Roll of Co. "G" of that Regiment, dated Hides Rendezvous, 2nd, 6th, 1862, he is reported "Recd. of disease in field Hospital Co. No. 6/61."

I am, Sir, very respectfully,
Your obedient servant,

E. W. Taggart

# JOINT AFFIDAVIT.
## ARMY PENSION—WIDOW CLAIMANT.

We, John Dixon, of lawful age, a resident of the (1) County of Richmond, in the State of Kentucky, at James Sutton, of lawful age, a resident of the (1) County of Richmond, in the State of Kentucky, upon our claim, jointly declare that he was personally well acquainted with Mrs. Kean Chambers, widow of (1) Aaron Chambers, now deceased, and was not sent to Private in Company E, commanded by Captain Moore, in the 1818 Regiment of (2) United States Colored Volunteers, commanded by Colonel Moore, in the war of 1776-1778.

We further declare that we were likewise personally well acquainted with the said (1) Aaron Chambers, deceased, and his said wife, the said Mrs. Kean Chambers, during the lifetime of the former, and know that they lived and exhibited together as husband and wife for the period at least of (2) Twenty years prior to his death, which length of time in the longest period of cohabitation, known to us. That said parties were reported as husband and wife, and that we never heard a question raised or a doubt concerned to the contrary as to their being such. Furthermore, we have often heard the said (1) Aaron Chambers call the said Mrs. Kean Chambers "wife," and always heard him speak of, and know that he ever treated and suspected her as such relation. We also state that she is esteemed and known as a respectable woman in the community of her residence.

We further declare that at the time of service, we resided in the army, established, County and State with the deceased soldier, and know that he, the said (1) Aaron Chambers, previous to his entering the said service of the United States, was a man of good sound physical health. Our knowledge of said soldier's physical condition prior to enlistment, as above stated, is finished upon several observations and intimate acquaintance with him and not heard upon information derived from others, nor upon general reason. That he died (1) While in the service aforesaid in the (1) United States, in the State of Virginia on or about the Sixth day of November A.D. 1864, from the effects of (2) Wounds, described in the service of the United States, and as we verily believe from general reports, and without the slightest doubt to the contrary, while in the line of his duty therein. That Mrs. Kean Chambers, his widow aforesaid, applying for Army Pension by reason of the above named military service, is now a widow, and has remained such ever since the death of her said husband, the said (1) Aaron Chambers, above mentioned. That we make this affidavit as a simple act of justice to the applicant, and for an other purpose, having an interest in so doing whatsoever. That we fully understand the import and meaning of all the facts embodied in this affidavit, and to which we freely testify.

B. E. Thornton
J. T. Weller
John Dixon
Justice of the Peace
Mark

B. E. Thornton

State of Kentucky County of Indiana SS.
On this 21st day of August A.D. 1867, before me H. S. Park, a Notary Public, I certify that the law of the State of Kentucky, is entitled to credit for the services rendered and paid by him, and that the pensioner is entitled to receive a pension of the 7th of July, 1866, being by me duly sworn according to law, on oath, that he is the true and lawful widow of Solomon Charles, decd. late a Private Company, Co. 111th U.S. Inf. Infantry, who died in field Hospital, State of Virginia, on the 21st day of November, 1866, from the affiant of Christian Anderson, for the time of duty.

She further declares she is unable to obtain a certificate from the Surgeon of this Regiment or Company, Virginia, for the reason that they were all withheld and do not reside in the Community of this residence, and in lieu of the above named certificate. She lives with said, the affidavit of two of his fellow soldiers, as to the cause and place of this death, not being the best evidence she is able to obtain.

She further swears, she cannot send record proof of her marriage with the above mentioned soldier, and for the reason that the law of the State, and not requiring a license to a record for the marriage of Charles of Color, but recognizing them as man and wife from the act of the Revolution, and she (Aaron) & her lived together as man and wife according to the law, in Kentucky, for persons of color, in proof of which she lives with and the affidavit of two or another witnesses.

Dennis C. Spinkers
Notary Public
ATTEST.
P. C. Thornton
S. T. Miller

Sir:

It appears from the Rolls on file in this Office, that Aaron Chamber was enrolled on the 19th day of Sept., 1861, at Owensboro, Ky., in Co. "G" 118th Regiment of U.S. Col. Infty Volunteers, to serve three years, or during the war, and mustered into service as a Private on the 19th day of Sept., 1861, at Owensboro, Ky., in Co. "G" 118th Regiment of U.S. Col. Infty Volunteers, to serve three years, or during the war. On the Muster Roll of Co. "G" of that Regiment, dated Hides Rendezvous, 2nd, 6th, 1862, he is reported "Recd. of disease in field Hospital Co. No. 6/61."

I am, Sir, very respectfully,
Your obedient servant,

# JOINT AFFIDAVIT.
## ARMY PENSION—WIDOW CLAIMANT.

We, John Dixon, of lawful age, a resident of the (1) County of Richmond, in the State of Kentucky, at James Sutton, of lawful age, a resident of the (1) County of Richmond, in the State of Kentucky, upon our claim, jointly declare that he was personally well acquainted with Mrs. Kean Chambers, widow of (1) Aaron Chambers, now deceased, and was not sent to Private in Company E, commanded by Captain Moore, in the 1818 Regiment of (2) United States Colored Volunteers, commanded by Colonel Moore, in the war of 1776-1778.

We further declare that we were likewise personally well acquainted with the said (1) Aaron Chambers, deceased, and his said wife, the said Mrs. Kean Chambers, during the lifetime of the former, and know that they lived and exhibited together as husband and wife for the period at least of (2) Twenty years prior to his death, which length of time in the longest period of cohabitation, known to us. That said parties were reported as husband and wife, and that we never heard a question raised or a doubt concerned to the contrary as to their being such. Furthermore, we have often heard the said (1) Aaron Chambers call the said Mrs. Kean Chambers "wife," and always heard him speak of, and know that he ever treated and suspected her as such relation. We also state that she is esteemed and known as a respectable woman in the community of her residence.

We further declare that at the time of service, we resided in the army, established, County and State with the deceased soldier, and know that he, the said (1) Aaron Chambers, previous to his entering the said service of the United States, was a man of good sound physical health. Our knowledge of said soldier's physical condition prior to enlistment, as above stated, is finished upon several observations and intimate acquaintance with him and not heard upon information derived from others, nor upon general reason. That he died (1) While in the service aforesaid in the (1) United States, in the State of Virginia on or about the Sixth day of November A.D. 1864, from the effects of (2) Wounds, described in the service of the United States, and as we verily believe from general reports, and without the slightest doubt to the contrary, while in the line of his duty therein. That Mrs. Kean Chambers, his widow aforesaid, applying for Army Pension by reason of the above named military service, is now a widow, and has remained such ever since the death of her said husband, the said (1) Aaron Chambers, above mentioned. That we make this affidavit as a simple act of justice to the applicant, and for an other purpose, having an interest in so doing whatsoever. That we fully understand the import and meaning of all the facts embodied in this affidavit, and to which we freely testify.

Register of Pensions,
No.

State of Kentucky County of Indiana SS.
On this 21st day of August A.D. 1867, before me H. S. Park, a Notary Public, I certify that the law of the State of Kentucky, is entitled to credit for the services rendered and paid by him, and that the pensioner is entitled to receive a pension of the 7th of July, 1866, being by me duly sworn according to law, on oath, that he is the true and lawful widow of Solomon Charles, decd. late a Private Company, Co. 111th U.S. Inf. Infantry, who died in field Hospital, State of Virginia, on the 21st day of November, 1866, from the affiant of Christian Anderson, for the time of duty.

She further declares she is unable to obtain a certificate from the Surgeon of this Regiment or Company, Virginia, for the reason that they were all withheld and do not reside in the Community of this residence, and in lieu of the above named certificate. She lives with said, the affidavit of two of his fellow soldiers, as to the cause and place of this death, not being the best evidence she is able to obtain.

She further swears, she cannot send record proof of her marriage with the above mentioned soldier, and for the reason that the law of the State, and not requiring a license to a record for the marriage of Charles of Color, but recognizing them as man and wife from the act of the Revolution, and she (Aaron) & her lived together as man and wife according to the law, in Kentucky, for persons of color, in proof of which she lives with and the affidavit of two or another witnesses.

Dennis C. Spinkers
Notary Public
ATTEST.
P. C. Thornton
S. T. Miller

Sworn to and subscribed before me, this 21st day of August, in the year 1867, and I hereby certify that the affiant is a respectable and credible person and made an oath, that I believe ——
and correct and worthy of full faith and credit, that I have no interest in this matter. I further certify that the foregoing affidavit was read, read, fully explained, to, and understood by the affiant before the signing and execution thereof, and also that the affiant is the identical party represented as making the affidavit.

H. S. Park
N. D. H. C.

transcribe_handwriting.text:
Dear Sir,

I received yr [your] letter
of the 5th Inst. and
am obliged for the
particulars sent.

The weather has been
extremely cold of late,
with heavy snow.

Yrs [Yours] sincerely,
John Smith
